Package algorithms.compGeometry.convexHull

Class GrahamScan

java.lang.Object
algorithms.compGeometry.convexHull.GrahamScan
public class GrahamScan extends Object
adapted from https://code.google.com/p/two-point-correlation/source/browse/src/test/java/algorithms/compGeometry/convexHull/ under MIT License (MIT), Nichole King 2013 
  Solves the Convex Hull problem w/ a stack S of candidate points.

  Given a set of Q points returns the vertices of the ConvexHull(Q) in clockwise
  order.   a convex hull is the smallest convex polygon that will include all points in Q.

  Graham's Scan runs in O(n lg n).
    (in contrast to Jarvis's March which runs in O(nh) where h is the number of
    vertices in the convex hull.)
  Will adjust this after estimates...

  Both use a technique called 'rotational sweep' to process vertices in the order
  of the polar angles they form with a reference vertex.

  constructed from pseudo-code in Cormen et al. "Introduction to Algorithms
first implemented in project https://github.com/nking/curvature-scale-space-corners-and-transformations w/ Copyright (c) 2014 Climb With Your Feet and using The MIT License (MIT) then moved to this shared library project which has the same copyright and license.
Author:
nichole

      public GrahamScan()

  • Method Details

    • computeHull

      public GrahamScan.CHD computeHull(float[] x, float[] y, boolean useLinearSort) throws GrahamScanTooFewPointsException
      find the convex hull of the given (x, y) points. Note that the resulting hull points have the same first point as last point. The runtime complexity is O(N*log_2(N)) if useLinearSort is false, wlse is O(N) if useLinearSort is true.
      Parameters:
      x -
      y -
      useLinearSort - if true, a linear runtime complexity algorithm is used (CountingSort or BucketSort depending upon the range of data and number of points. If the range of data is 0 to 359 and x.length >= 360, then counting sort is used with a resolution of 1 degree.
      Returns:
      the convex hull of (x, y)
      Throws:
      GrahamScanTooFewPointsException

    • computeHull

      public GrahamScan.CHD computeHull(double[] x, double[] y, boolean useLinearSort) throws GrahamScanTooFewPointsException
      find the convex hull of the given (x, y) points. Note that the resulting hull points have the same first point as last point. The runtime complexity is O(N*log_2(N)) if useLinearSort is false, wlse is O(N) if useLinearSort is true.
      Parameters:

      y -
      useLinearSort - if true, a linear runtime complexity algorithm is used (CountingSort or BucketSort depending upon the range of data and number of points. If the range of data is 0 to 359 and x.length >= 360, then counting sort is used with a resolution of 1 degree.
      Returns:
      the convex hull of (x, y)

    • computeHull

      find the convex hull of the given (x, y) points. Note that the resulting hull points have the same first point as last point. The runtime complexity is O(N*log_2(N)) if useLinearSort is false, wlse is O(N) if useLinearSort is true.
      Parameters:

      useLinearSort - if true, a linear runtime complexity algorithm is used (CountingSort or BucketSort depending upon the range of data and number of points. If the range of data is 0 to 359 and x.length >= 360, then counting sort is used with a resolution of 1 degree.
